message.content: This question requires some knowledge of how sound waves travel. When sound waves encounter an obstacle, such as a canyon wall, they will reflect off the surface, causing an echo. This phenomenon is known as sound reflection. Option (B) is incorrect because sound cannot travel in the vacuum of outer space due to the absence of air or any other medium for the sound waves to travel through. Option (C) is incorrect because sound waves can travel through water in the ocean, but they do not reflect off the surface of the water. Option (D) is incorrect because a vacuum does not contain any air or matter for sound waves to travel through, so they cannot reflect off any surfaces.

This question requires knowledge about the properties of sound and how it behaves in different environments. When sound waves encounter surfaces, they can bounce off and be reflected. This phenomenon is known as sound reflection. Option (A) is the correct answer because canyons have reflective surfaces such as rock walls that allow sound to bounce off and be heard. Option (B) is incorrect because sound cannot travel in the vacuum of outer space. Option (C) is partially correct because sound does reflect off the surface of water in the ocean, but it can also travel through the water. Option (D) is incorrect because a vacuum does not have any particles for sound to reflect off, resulting in no sound being heard.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of sound waves. When sound waves encounter a surface, they can bounce back and reflect off that surface. This phenomenon is known as sound reflection. Option (A) is correct because in a canyon, the walls of the canyon can cause sound waves to bounce back and be heard again. Option (B) is incorrect because sound cannot travel in outer space, as there is no medium for the sound waves to propagate through. Option (C) is incorrect because sound travels well in water, so it is not typically reflected off the surfaces in the ocean. Option (D) is incorrect because a vacuum is an environment devoid of air or any other medium for sound waves to travel through, so there would be no surfaces for sound to reflect off.

This question requires basic knowledge about how sound waves travel and interact with different environments. When sound waves encounter a solid surface, such as the walls of a canyon, they can reflect off the surface and create echoes. This is why option (A) is correct. Option (B), outer space, is incorrect because sound cannot travel through the vacuum of space. Option (C), in the ocean, is also correct as sound waves can reflect off the surface of the water and propagate through it. Option (D), in a vacuum, is incorrect because sound waves require a medium to propagate and cannot travel through a vacuum.

This question requires knowledge about the behavior of sound waves. Sound waves can be reflected off surfaces, such as walls or canyons, and this reflection can be heard by our ears. Option (B) is incorrect because outer space is a vacuum and sound waves cannot travel through a vacuum. Option (C) is incorrect because sound waves travel faster in water than in air, so the reflection off surfaces in the ocean is less noticeable. Option (D) is incorrect because a vacuum does not have any particles for sound waves to travel through, so there would be no sound to reflect.
